title.narrative: Health emergency response to Hurricanes Eta and Iota in Nicaragua

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to ensure access to life-saving healthcare services and actions to reduce the impact of the humanitarian crisis. This WHO project provides a 3-month supply of essential medications and supplies to support 9 health facilities, Inter-Agency Reproductive Health Kits to 22 facilities, PPEs for health workers and community health volunteers, and vector control supplies and equipment. The project provides life-saving assistance to approximately 69,000 people, including 22,000 women, 21,000 men, 26,000 children, and 7,000 people with disabilities.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to CERF Project Health emergency response to Hurricanes Eta and Iota in Nicaragua

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS NICARAGUA RAPID RESPONSE STORM 2020

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: 68,578 community members in affected areas have continued access to essential community-based health services, including maternal and child health care, sexual and reproductive health, communicable and non-communicable diseases care, and mental health.
Number of health consultations provided by comprehensive intercultural healthcare teams in priority communities affected by the storms.
Number of health facilities equipped with essential medications and supplies, including IARH kits and SHR supplies, serving the target population.
Community members living in impacted areas are protected against risk of vector-borne diseases outbreaks and other public health threats
Number of health workers and community health volunteers provided with personal protective equipment.
Number of homes receiving mosquito control measures provided by vector control teams in priority municipalities.
